poem.author: Peter McCarey
poem.text: A gravel drive, a motor park A message on the doorbell: go Around the outhouse, where the lawn Swoops down like a darkened cinema A room projects from the house above One flock of yachts, a candle lit Pavilion on a silver sea. The mortgage owners never showed. I fled. It rained. Civility. Joe Pass, put down that guitar And tell me, if you know, That every drop is counterweighted In another life - The one in black that ought to wear Just flame red, and not much of it. Whose every dream is sunk and countersunk.
